message.content:
cs.DS, cs.GT, cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.SI. 

The paper deals with a combinatorial problem related to scheduling and graph theory, which suggests that it could belong to several sub-categories. The use of independent sets and the objective of minimizing the maximal gap between appearances of a node indicate that it could belong to cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) or cs.GT (Computer Science and Game Theory). The connections with periodic scheduling and universal prefix-free encodings suggest that it could also belong to cs.IT (Information Theory) or cs.SI (Social and Information Networks). Finally, the application to scheduling of transmissions made by cellular radios suggests that it could belong to cs.NI (Networking and Internet Architecture).
